issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: Signifies completion of tasks, info requests, etc.
resolution.name: Completed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

fields.description:
I was testing on the scale setup with 4897 instances. I think I tracked the problem to a fetch of images where the list of IDs can be greatly reduced by removing duplicates. Testing a fix now.

Does DescribeImages w/ a filter handle many of the same Image Ids in that filter by returning multiple duplicate records? This might be what's really happening, but I'm hoping to supply a sane list of ids on the client in any case.
fields.summary: Console instance landing page doesn't handle large lists of instances

comments.body: [~tony] thinks that if duplicates start appearing after 2K instances, we can put this off until a sub-minor release. [~dkavanagh] to investigate.
[~dkavanagh], [~dmitrii]: This ticket was confirmed but doesn't have a fix version atm.  Is it scoped for 4.3?
[~kgill], per the comment, we may put this off.

I've determined the limit is between 3125 and 3250 instances (with the same image ID).  The fix is super low risk, so while it doesn't need to be in 4.3, it really won't hurt. If it broke 4.3, our CI tests cover that page.
I vote to include this in 4.3.0, as the fix is extremely low-risk.
[~alice], [~tony]: Ok if we include this in 4.3.0?  See prior comments for regression potential and risk.

Another reason to include this in 4.3.0 is the significant reduction in API response payload size as the number of instances increases, especially if many of those instances are launched from a common image.

[~dkavanagh] what was your test case exactly? Can you describe the steps that you took? 
We need to determine what would be the tests to verify this fix.
I pointed it at the scale-test cloud which had 4897 instances running. It seems the limit is around 3250 instances, so you'd need that many running to verify this.
[~kgill], [~dkavanagh], and [~alice] let's go ahead and put this into 4.3.0
simple fix. [~kgill] already looked at it.
